continent.name: Anger
continent.desc: The Anger actions differ not only in their strength but also in how they deal with what triggered the anger.

states.name: Annoyance
states.desc: The mildest state of anger, never felt very strongly.

states.name: Frustration
states.desc: A loss of patience with a person or task.

states.name: Argumentativeness
states.desc: An inclination to partake in unfriendly verbal disagreements.

states.name: Bitterness
states.desc: The residue from having been repeatedly angry, usually due to feeling that the world is populated by people or events that block pursuit of what is important to you.

states.name: Exasperation
states.desc: The feeling of losing patience with a person or task that is generating an overload of frustration.

states.name: Vengefulness
states.desc: A strong desire to harm someone who has harmed you.

states.name: Fury
states.desc: The highest, most intense state of anger, often resulting in a loss of control. May also result in violent actions.

actions.name: Quarrel
actions.desc: Verbally oppose in a manner intended to escalate the disagreement.

actions.name: Insult
actions.desc: Disparage the other person in a offensive or hurtful way that is likely to escalate the conflict rather than resolve it.

actions.name: Undermine
actions.desc: Take action to make someone or something weaker or less effective, usually in a secret or gradual way.

actions.name: Dispute
actions.desc: Disagree in a manner that may escalate the dispute.

actions.name: Scream/yell
actions.desc: Lose control of how one speaks; speak in a loud volume and, when screaming, in a higher pitch.

actions.name: Use physical force
actions.desc: Harm or constrain someone, an action that may be deliberately chosen or the result of a loss of control over how one acts.

actions.name: Be firm
actions.desc: Convey that one's position is strongly held, not likely to be abandoned.

actions.name: Withdraw
actions.desc: Physically or mentally leave the scene of the conflict.

actions.name: Take a time out
actions.desc: Announce intention to withdraw to prevent escalation of the conflict.

actions.name: Practice patience
actions.desc: Regard the conflict as an opportunity to not lose one's temper.

actions.name: Suppress
actions.desc: Try to avoid feeling or acting upon the emotion that is being experienced.

actions.name: Distract
actions.desc: Engage in other activities in an attempt to avoid feeling this emotion.

actions.name: Avoid
actions.desc: Either physically stay away from someone or something, or internally keep one’s mind away from what is triggering the anger.

actions.name: Simmer/brood
actions.desc: Act in a way that makes clear that angry actions are building or being contemplated.

actions.name: Be passive-aggressive
actions.desc: Take indirect actions that have an angry undercurrent.

actions.name: Remove the interference
actions.desc: Attempt to eliminate whatever is blocking the pursuit of a goal.

triggers: Being put down by an authority figure

moods.name: Irritable
moods.desc: A readiness, a need to become angry. Filtering perceptions to see provocations not noticed when not irritable.

continent.name: Fear
continent.desc: Fear is the response to perceived danger.

states.name: Trepidation
states.desc: A sense of slight danger, often pending but not immediate.

states.name: Nervousness
states.desc: Perception of a danger that you do not know how to respond to.

states.name: Anxiety
states.desc: Apprehensiveness about an anticipated or unspecified threat.

states.name: Dread
states.desc: Anticipation of severe danger from which there is no protection or escape.

states.name: Desperation
states.desc: Realization of the futility of our attempts to reduce danger.

states.name: Panic
states.desc: A consequence of desperation.

states.name: Horror
states.desc: A mixture of fear and disgust which probably alternate quickly rather than merge together.

states.name: Terror
states.desc: The most extreme fear that can be felt.

actions.name: Withdraw
actions.desc: Physically or mentally leave the scene of the threat.

actions.name: Avoid
actions.desc: Either physically stay away from someone or something, or internally keep one’s mind away from what is triggering the fear.

actions.name: Hesitate
actions.desc: Hold back in doubt or indecision, often momentarily.

actions.name: Freeze
actions.desc: Become incapable of acting or speaking.

actions.name: Scream/yell
actions.desc: Lose control of how one speaks; speak in a loud volume and, when screaming, in a higher pitch.

actions.name: Reframe
actions.desc: Reconsider the emotional trigger in an attempt to reduce or eliminate it.

actions.name: Be mindful
actions.desc: Accept how you feel and recognize that it's temporary.

actions.name: Breathe
actions.desc: Focus awareness on breathing in order to diminish fearful feelings.

actions.name: Ruminate
actions.desc: Repetitively think about the emotional experience.

actions.name: Worry
actions.desc: Anticipate the possibility of harm.

actions.name: Distract
actions.desc: Engage in other activities in an attempt to avoid feeling this emotion.

moods.name: Apprehensive
moods.desc: Expecting harm but not knowing how to avoid it. Perceiving threats when they are not there, or magnifying the seriousness of a threat.

continent.name: Disgust
continent.desc: We are disgusted by anything that is literally or physically toxic.

states.name: Aversion
states.desc: A desire to avoid something noxious.

states.name: Dislike
states.desc: Disapproval of a thing, person or action.

states.name: Distaste
states.desc: Offense caused by a taste or smell; metaphorically, offense caused by sights or actions.

states.name: Repugnance
states.desc: Repulsion to something literally or figuratively toxic.

states.name: Loathing
states.desc: Intense repulsion to a thing or person.

states.name: Revulsion
states.desc: Very strong repulsion that usually implies a movement away from the source.

states.name: Abhorrence
states.desc: Extreme repulsion to the look, smell or taste of toxic sustances, or to highly offensive actions.

actions.name: Withdraw
actions.desc: Physically or mentally leave the scene of what is triggering the disgust.

actions.name: Avoid
actions.desc: Either phsyically stay away from someone or something, or internally keep one's mind away from what is triggering the disgust.

actions.name: Vomit
actions.desc: Expel material from the stomach via the mouth; metaphorically denotes very intense disgust.

actions.name: Dehumanize
actions.desc: Treat someone as though he or she is not a human being; deprive someone of human qualities, personality or spirit.

triggers: Anything coming out of the body
Fans of an opposing sports team

moods.name: Sour
moods.desc: Not commonly a mood, it can occur as a mood when there is a generalized feeling of repugnance or revulsion — usually of low intensity.

continent.name: Sadness
continent.desc: We experience sadness at the actual or perceived loss of a person to whom we are attached, such as a parent or child, a lover or a close friend; at a loss of our own health or social status; and at a loss of an object that we value highly.

states.name: Disappointment
states.desc: A feeling that expectations are not being met.

states.name: Distraughtness
states.desc: Agitated sadness. Felt intensely and often for long periods.

states.name: Discouragement
states.desc: A feeling that there is no way to cope with an actual or potential loss.

states.name: Resignation
states.desc: Acceptance that nothing can be done to prevent an important loss.

states.name: Helplessness
states.desc: Realization of the inability to prevent or cope with loss.

states.name: Misery
states.desc: An intense, prolonged feeling of anguish.

states.name: Grief
states.desc: Anguish aroused by the death of a loved one. Varies over time, from very intense at the time of the death to intermittently moderate as time goes on.

states.name: Despair
states.desc: Resigned anguish.

states.name: Sorrow
states.desc: Response to an important loss.

states.name: Anguish
states.desc: Intense agitation. Protesting form of despair over an actual or expected loss.

states.name: Hopelessness
states.desc: NEED DESCRIPTION

actions.name: Seek comfort
actions.desc: Seek help or support from others.

actions.name: Withdraw
actions.desc: Physically or mentally leave the scene of what is triggering the sadness.

actions.name: Ruminate
actions.desc: Repetitively think about the emotional experience.

actions.name: Mourn
actions.desc: Focus on the loss.

actions.name: Protest
actions.desc: Complain about the loss, knowing that the complaint will not recover what was lost.

actions.name: Feel ashamed
actions.desc: Feel the need to hide how one feels about what or who is lost.

actions.name: Distract
actions.desc: Engage in other activities in an attempt to avoid feeling this emotion.

triggers: Not being invited to a party

moods.name: Dysphoria (or feeling blue)
moods.desc: Feelings of resignation, discouragement or disappointment that endure for a long period. The anguished side of sadness does not transform into a mood.

continent.name: Enjoyment
continent.desc: The pursuit of what feels good is a primary motive in our lives.

states.name: Sensory Pleasures
states.desc: NEED DESCRIPTION

states.name: Relief
states.desc: When something expected to be unplesant, especialy the threat of harm, is avoided or comes to an end.

states.name: Amusement
states.desc: Light, playful, humorous feelings of enjoyment.

states.name: Excitement
states.desc: Energetic pursuit that, unlike other enjoyable emotions, is rarely felt slightly, but ranges from mid to high in intesnity. May merge with any of the emotions generate a very active form of that emotion.

states.name: Ecstasy
states.desc: Rapturous delight. A state of very great happiness, nearly overwhelming.

states.name: Fiero
states.desc: An Italian word that descrives the enjoyment felt when you have met a challenge that stretched your capabilities.

states.name: Naches
states.desc: The Yiddish word for feelings of pride in the accomplishments, or sometimes just the existence, of your actual offspring, or mentored offspring. Crucial for motivating the nurture of infants and children.

states.name: Wonder
states.desc: Experiencing something that is very surprising, beautiful, amazing, or hard to believe.

states.name: Schadenfreude
states.desc: Enjoying the misfortunes of another person, usually a rival.

states.name: Rejoicing
states.desc: A warm, uplifting feeling that people experience when they see acts of human goodness, kindness, and compassion. Also called elevation.

states.name: Compassion-joy
states.desc: Enjoyment felt when you act compassionately, especially if your actions help to relieve another person's suffering.

states.name: Pride
states.desc: Wanting others to know the pleasure you feel in your own accomplishments or the accomplishments of another who you either nurtured directly or identified with.

states.name: Debauchery
states.desc: NEED DESCRIPTION

actions.name: Withdraw
actions.desc: To physically or mentally leave the scene.

actions.name: Seek more
actions.desc: To increase the enjoyable feelings.

actions.name: Maintain
actions.desc: To continue to do what is necessary to continue the enjoyable feelings.

actions.name: Gloat
actions.desc: To enjoy others envying your enjoyable state.

actions.name: Exclaim
actions.desc: To vocally express enjoyment to others.

actions.name: Engage/Connect
actions.desc: To desire connection and engagement with others to share in feelings of enjoyment.

actions.name: Savor
actions.desc: To relish in the experience of good feelings about the felt and psychological experiences.

actions.name: Indulge
actions.desc: Excessively engaging in the enjoyable feelings

moods.name: High
moods.desc: Generalized, non-specific feeling good not about any trigger; lasting hours.

intro.body:
This collection of maps was created by Paul and Eve Ekman to help you better understand your emotions, where they come from and the effects they have on your life.

Navigate by scrolling between sections or by using the right-hand navigation bar, and by clicking elements to dig deeper.

This is an opportunity for you to explore the vast world of emotions. The atlas begins with what scholars agree on and gradually introduces the Ekmans' working hypotheses about more complex subject matter.

continents.body: Each emotion is represented as a continent. The movement of the continents reflects how emotions vary in strength and frequency in people's lives.

states.body: Each emotion contains a number of related but different states. These states differ not only in their nature but in their intensity. The states listed below are representative, not exhaustive.

actions.body: Each emotional state can result in a number of likely actions. Click on a state to see whether an action is constructive or destructive.

qualities.body: Actions that further future collaboration with others.
Actions that decrease the likelihood of being able to collaborate with others.
Sometimes an action can be both constructive and destructive, depending on the context.

triggers.body: Triggers automatically bring forth an emotion without consideration.

steps.body: Some triggers are universal, some are cultural, and some are individual.
We can become emotional about anything: the world around us, both novel and familiar, and our own expectations and memories.
It is very difficult to modify our emotional actions once triggered. Identifying what triggers our emotions may enable us to lead a more balanced emotional life.
Universal triggers are innate, common to everyone. They affect us more intensely than learned triggers.
Learned triggers are either cultural, stemming from widely shared experiences, or personal, arising from more individual experiences.

moods.body: Moods are longer-lasting cousins of emotions that cause the related emotion to be felt more frequently and intensely. It is not always apparent what triggers a mood.

calm.body: Calm is a state of mind that is actively engaged in using intelligence and wisdom to evaulate the changing world.

secondary.body: To learn more about emotions, click on "more information" to the right.
